This course is focused on programming the essential geometric and mathematical concepts underlying modern computer graphics. Using 2D and 3D implementations, it covers fundamental topics on scene graphs, computational geometry, graphics algorithms, and user interface design. Programming languages introduced include C++, OpenGL, and Qt.

Overall, students described the course as rewarding and helpful, but extremely difficult and even torturous at times. Many indicated that it was “the most time intensive course” they have taken at Penn and that “the material taught during class is very disconnected to the homework.” Although most students gained a newfound appreciation for computer graphics and programming by the end of the class, they spent an enormous amount of time teaching themselves them material and completing the homework.

The majority of students expressed gratitude to their TAs for their willingness to help, and found their office hours extremely valuable. Some commented that they would have barely passed this course “if it weren’t for the incredible team of TAs.” Meanwhile, Professor Badler was regarded as “non-existent throughout this course.” Students reported that he “rarely [showed] up in office hours,” and did not organize the course well. Others noted that the homework files were “vague” and that the slides were not helpful.

The course is required for DMD majors, but is also recommended to CIS majors. The prerequisite is CIS 120. CIS 121 and CIS 240 are useful as pre- or co-requisites. Students wishing to take this course should be wary of the great time commitment.

Using 2D and 3D implementations, it covers fundamental topics on scene graphs, computational geometry, graphics algorithms, and user interface design. Programming languages introduced include C++, OpenGL, FLTK and Python.

Students overall found this course to be a “great class” in which they “learned a lot of interesting things.”

Most students felt that to succeed in the course “you had to teach yourself.” Students also felt the TAs “were very willing to help,” and “sometimes offered more intuitive explanations than the instructor.”

Students found that the course was “extremely difficult” with “a ton of work,” with homework assignments requiring “20-40 hours a week.” Some students even warn, “Do not take unless you have to.”
